impulse.level: Control the level of the input signal. The value of this parameter directly corresponds to the amplitude of the impulse sample.
impulse.density: Control the length of the impulse, in samples. Higher values induce a low-pass effect.

noise.level: Control the level of the white noise signal. The value of this parameter directly corresponds to the amplitude of the white noise

sampler.gain: Control the gain of the sampler, in decibels.
sampler.loop: If enabled, the sampler will loop the sample indefinitely, between the start and end positions. If disabled, the sampler will play the sample once and then stop.
sampler.start: Choose where playback should start. A value of 0 corresponds to the beginning of the sample, and a value of 1 corresponds to the end of the sample.
sampler.end: Choose where playback should end. A value of 0 corresponds to the beginning of the sample, and a value of 1 corresponds to the end of the sample.

external.gain: Control the gain of the external input signal, in decibels.
external.constantnote: If enabled, a constant MIDI note will be supplied to the instrument at all times, allowing Resonarium to be used as an audio effect without complex MIDI routing. MIDI input from the host will still be processed and played as normal while this parameter is engaged.
external.constantnotefrequency: Set the frequency of the constant MIDI note. This is implemented via a MIDI MPE pitch bend signal; therefore, the frequency range is limited by the MPE pitch bend range. At a default value of +-48 semitones, this parameter is bounded between ~10 Hz and ~3000 Hz. Values exceeding this range are clamped appropriately.

resonator.gain: Control the gain of the resonator.
resonator.solo: Solo the resonator, intercepting and routing its output directly to the main output. The output of the rest of the synth will be silenced.
resonator.pitch: Set the pitch of the resonator with respect to the current MIDI note. The resonator will produce sound at this frequency, and will resonate strongly with any harmonically related input signals.
resonator.frequency: Set the absolute frequency of the resonator, unrelated to the current MIDI note. The resonator will produce sound at this frequency, and will resonate strongly with any harmonically related input signals.
resonator.keytrack: If enabled, the resonator can be tuned with respect to the current MIDI note. Otherwise, the resonator can be tuned to a constant frequency.
resonator.decay: Adjust the decay time of the resonator. Lower values correspond to stronger damping and a shorter note. If set to zero, the resonator will be bypassed entirely and the exciter signal will pass through to the post filter.
resonator.dispersion: Dispersion occurs when different frequencies travel at different speeds through a vibrating object. This parameter controls the amount of dispersion in the resonator. Higher values induce a inharmonic, metallic timbre.
resonator.loopfilterkeytrack: If enabled, the loop filter's cutoff frequency will be set with respect to the current MIDI note. Otherwise, the filter cutoff can be set to a constant frequency.
resonator.loopfiltercutoff: Set the cutoff frequency of the waveguide filter. This corresponds to damping present in the string. Higher cutoff frequencies produce a brighter sound. When in keytrack mode, the filter's resonant frequency is tuned to the current MIDI note with respect to this offset.
resonator.loopfilterresonance: Set the resonance of the waveguide filter. Higher resonance values induce waveguide resonance at the peak frequency of the filter, which is tuned to the current MIDI note when in keytrack mode. When resonance is nonzero, waveguide will be strongly damped at all other frequencies.
resonator.loopfiltermode: Choose whether the waveguide filter should be a low-pass filter, band-pass filter, or high-pass filter.

resonatorbank.inputgain: Set the gain of the input signal to the waveguide bank
resonatorbank.outputgain: Set the gain of the waveguide bank's output
resonatorbank.inputmix: Mix between the exciter signal and the previous waveguide bank's output signal. Has no effect on the first waveguide bank.
resonatorbank.coupling: Set the coupling mode employed by this waveguide bank. In parallel mode, each resonator is excited individually by the input signal. In interlinked mode, the output of all resonators is fed into the input of each resonator. In cascade mode, the output of the nth resonator is fed into the input of the n+1th resonator.
resonatorbank.cascadeamount: Set the level of each cascade signal between adjacent resonators. The output of the nth resonator will be multiplied by this amount before being fed into the n+1th resonator.
resonatorbank.cascadefiltercutoff: Set the cutoff frequency of the filter applied to each cascade signal.
resonatorbank.cascadefilterresonance: Set the resonance of the filter applied to each cascade signal. Higher values produce a more pronounced peak at the cutoff frequency.
resonatorbank.cascadefiltermode: Set the mode of the cascade signal filters. A mode of 0 corresponds to a lowpass filter, a mode of 0.5 corresponds to a bandpass filter, and a mode of 1 corresponds to a highpass filter. Intermediate values interpolate these extrema.
resonatorbank.usesemitones:
Toggle resonator tuning by semitones or by frequency multiplier. If enabled, the resonator frequency will be modified by the number of semitones in the Pitch field. If disabled, the resonator frequency will be multiplied by the value in the Pitch field.

This is a quality-of-life feature and has no effect on the timbre of the resonator.

modulation.sync: Sync the rate of this modulation source to the host tempo.

env.attack: Set the attack time of the envelope, in seconds.
env.decay: Set the decay time of the envelope, in seconds.
env.sustain: Set the sustain level of the envelope, as a fraction of the peak level.
env.release: Set the release time of the envelope, in seconds.

lfo.rate: Set the rate of the LFO, in Hertz.
lfo.retrig: Choose whether to retrigger the LFO on each new note.
lfo.beat: Set the rate of the LFO with respect to the host tempo.
lfo.stereo: Set the phase offset between the left and right channels of the LFO. A value of 0 corresponds to a phase offset of 0 degrees, and a value of 1 corresponds to a phase offset of 180 degrees.
lfo.depth: Set the modulation depth of this LFO, i.e. the amplitude of the modulation signal.
lfo.phase: Apply a constant phase offset to the LFO.
lfo.wave: Choose the waveform of this LFO

rand.rate: Set the rate of the random modulation source, in Hertz. The modulator will sample and hold a new random value at this rate.
rand.beat: Set the rate of the random modulation source with respect to the host tempo.
rand.stereo: Choose how strongly the left and right channels of the random modulation source are correlated. A value of 0 corresponds to perfect correlation, and a value of 1 corresponds to total independence between the channels.
rand.depth: Set the modulation depth of this random modulation source, i.e. the amplitude of the modulation signal.
rand.chaos: Choose how similar each random value is to the previous random value. A value of 0 corresponds to a constant signal, whereas a value of 1 corresponds to a completely random signal.
rand.smooth: Smooth the transition between successive random samples.

delay.enable: Enable or disable the delay effect.
delay.time: Set the delay time in seconds for each channel.
delay.sync: Sync the delay time to the host tempo.
delay.beat: Set the delay time as a rhythmic division of the host tempo.
delay.feedback: Control how much of the delayed signal is fed back into the delay line. Higher values create more repeating echoes.
delay.mix: Set the balance between the dry (unprocessed) and wet (delayed) signals.
delay.pingpong: Enable ping-pong mode, which causes the echoes to alternate between left and right channels. Creates a wide stereo effect.
delay.lock: Link the left and right delay times. When enabled, both channels will use the left channel's time or beat setting.

chorus.enable: Enable or disable the chorus effect, which creates a shimmering, ensemble-like sound by layering slightly detuned copies of the signal.
chorus.rate: Set the rate at which the chorus effect modulates, affecting how quickly the sound waves together and apart.
chorus.sync: Sync the chorus rate to the host tempo.
chorus.beat: Set the chorus modulation rate as a rhythmic division of the host tempo.
chorus.depth: Control the intensity of the chorus effect. Higher values create a wider, more pronounced effect.
chorus.delay: Set the base delay time for the chorus, affecting the character of the effect. Longer delays create a more dramatic chorus sound.
chorus.feedback: Control how much of the chorus output is fed back into the effect. Higher values create a more complex, resonant chorus sound.
chorus.mix: Set the balance between the dry (unprocessed) and wet (chorus-processed) signals.

phaser.enable: Enable or disable the phaser effect, which creates a sweeping, swirling sound by creating notches in the frequency spectrum.
phaser.rate: Set the rate at which the phaser sweeps through the frequency spectrum.
phaser.sync: Sync the phaser rate to the host tempo.
phaser.beat: Set the phaser modulation rate as a rhythmic division of the host tempo.
phaser.depth: Control the intensity of the phaser effect. Higher values create a more dramatic sweeping effect.
phaser.centrefreq: Set the center frequency around which the phaser effect operates, affecting the tonal character of the effect.
phaser.feedback: Control how much of the phaser output is fed back into the effect. Higher positive or negative values create a more resonant, intense phaser sound.
phaser.mix: Set the balance between the dry (unprocessed) and wet (phaser-processed) signals.

reverb.enable: Enable or disable the reverb effect, which simulates acoustic space and adds ambience to the sound.
reverb.dampingfreq: Control how quickly high frequencies decay in the reverb. Higher values maintain more brightness in the reverb tail.
reverb.density: Adjust the density of reflections in the reverb. Higher values create a smoother, more diffuse reverb sound.
reverb.bandwidthfreq: Control the bandwidth of the input signal that gets processed by the reverb. Higher values maintain more of the original sound's character.
reverb.decay: Set how long the reverb tail persists. Higher values create a longer-lasting reverb effect.
reverb.predelay: Add a delay before the reverb begins, creating a sense of distance from the sound source.
reverb.size: Control the perceived size of the reverberant space. Higher values simulate larger rooms or halls.
reverb.earlymix: Adjust the balance between early reflections and the late reverb tail. Higher values emphasize the initial reflections.
reverb.mix: Set the balance between the dry (unprocessed) and wet (reverb-processed) signals.

compressor.enable: Enable or disable the compressor effect, which reduces the dynamic range of the audio by attenuating louder signals.
compressor.threshold: Set the level above which the compressor begins to reduce gain. Lower threshold values affect more of the signal.
compressor.ratio: Determine how strongly the compressor reduces signals above the threshold. Higher ratios create more aggressive compression.
compressor.attack: Set how quickly the compressor responds to signals exceeding the threshold. Shorter attack times catch transients more aggressively.
compressor.release: Control how long the compressor takes to stop reducing gain after the signal falls below the threshold. Longer release times create smoother compression.

distortion.enable: Enable or disable the distortion effect, which adds harmonics to the signal by applying non-linear processing.
distortion.type: Select the distortion algorithm. Options include soft clip for subtle warmth, hard clip for aggressive distortion, bit crush for digital artifacts, and more.
distortion.drive: Control the amount of gain applied to the signal before distortion. Higher values create more intense distortion effects.
distortion.outputgain: Adjust the level of the distorted signal, compensating for any volume increases caused by the distortion process.
distortion.mix: Set the balance between the dry (unprocessed) and wet (distorted) signals.
distortion.prepostfilter: Choose whether to apply filtering before distortion (pre), after distortion (post), or disable filtering entirely.
distortion.cutoff: Set the cutoff frequency of the distortion filter, determining which frequencies are affected by the filter.
distortion.resonance: Control the resonance of the distortion filter. Higher values create a peak at the cutoff frequency.
distortion.filtermode: Set whether the distortion filter operates as a lowpass (0.0), bandpass (0.5), or highpass (1.0) filter.

multiamp.enable: Enable or disable the amplifier simulation effect, which models various types of guitar amplifiers and tone-shaping circuits.
multiamp.mode: Select the amplifier model. Options include Lead, Bass, Fire, Big, Grind, and Bitcrush, each with its own characteristic sound.
multiamp.parama: Control the first parameter of the selected amp model. The effect varies depending on which amp model is selected.
multiamp.paramb: Control the second parameter of the selected amp model. The effect varies depending on which amp model is selected.
multiamp.paramc: Control the third parameter of the selected amp model. The effect varies depending on which amp model is selected.
multiamp.paramd: Control the fourth parameter of the selected amp model. The effect varies depending on which amp model is selected.

filter.enable: Enable or disable the filter effect, which shapes the tone by attenuating certain frequencies.
filter.freq: Set the cutoff frequency of the filter. For lowpass filters, frequencies above this point are attenuated; for highpass, frequencies below.
filter.mode: Control whether the filter operates as a lowpass (0.0), bandpass (0.5), or highpass (1.0) filter, with smooth interpolation between types.
filter.res: Set the resonance of the filter, which creates a peak at the cutoff frequency. Higher values create a more pronounced resonant peak.

global.gain: Set the gain of the output signal. This parameter is always polyphonic, and can be used by an envelope or LFO to modulate the output level.
global.polyfx: Choose whether to use polyphonic effect chains. If enabled, each note will have its own effect chain. If disabled, all notes will share a single effect chain. Disabling improves performance, but effect parameters will no longer be polyphonically modulable.
global.numvoices: Set the number of voices in the synthesizer. Each voice has its own effect chain and modulation sources. Increasing the number of voices will increase the CPU load.
global.stereo: Choose whether to enable stereo resonators. If enabled, resonators will maintain a different internal state for the left and right channels, and will support stereo modulation. Disabling will improve performance, but disable stereo effects from the resonators.
